training: Have you received any previous interview training outside of the current study?
training_desc: Briefly describe any previous interviewing training you have received below.
planning_int: Please assess how well you applied your training when you planned the interview.
conducting_int: Please assess how well you applied your training while conducting the interview.
new_info_interviewer: How much new information do you think you learned about the suspects activities from the interview?
training_qual: Please provide a brief description of how you applied the training to the planning and performance of the interview.
different_qual: Is there anything you would have liked to do differently regarding the interview?

training_qual: {"ImportId":"QID8_TEXT"}
different_qual: {"ImportId":"QID9_TEXT"}

training_qual: I planned open ended questions so that the suspect could freely talk and so as to not pressure or influence their answers. I made sure to write down questions about both the things that I knew already (such as what floors of a building the suspect had visited) and the things I did not know (like how they got from point A to B). I used training to start the interview by introducing myself, the purpose of the interview, and by asking the first open question "tell me about today".
different_qual: The performance of the interview went very differently to what I thought it would. The suspect did not speak as freely as I had hoped, and mostly just avoided my questions. This immediately made me ask more pressuring and closed questions, which was difficult to change mid-interview. It was also difficult to take time to think properly, as I didn't want to disrupt the flow of back and forth talking, and felt that being silent for long periods of time was awkward. So, there was a lot I would have liked to do differently. However, considering this is the first time I have done this, and the suspect did not answer questions the way I thought they would, I hope to be able to do better next time.

training_qual: In planning my intention was to ask as open questions as possible to have the suspect give their version of what happened during the day. I open and closed as instructed. The suspect was not very informative and I ended up asking quite a lot of 'closed' questions.
different_qual: Perhaps I should have confronted the person with the evidence provided. The suspect denied being anywhere else but in her office on the second floor whereas CCTV footage as well as witnesses testimonies contradicted this.

training_qual:
I applied what i learned about the planing process such as assessing the thing we know and we dont, creating a structure plan to guide me and pointing out the things I must ask about. 

In the interview I found it a little hard to follow the stroyline of the suspect and the information that was given right in the moment, it is like multitasking. But I managed to get new information and I felt proud about that and I had to keep myself stable when I realised the suspect gave information we did not know before.
different_qual: As an improvement for myself, -i must give attention to the little facts such as which key in which room opens which place, (what someone needs to do priorly for a particular action) . Because during the storyline i realised the importance of it and this was the reason how i got the new information as well.

training_desc: I have got about 2hours of interview training about the basics of interviewing, the opening and closing, good types of questions to ask, how to structure a interview etc
training_qual: I made a plan beforehand about the information I had and the information that I didn't have to better get a picture of what I wantet to ask about during the interviw. I also made a structure how to open the meeting, what to ask and how to close it. Then during the interview I tried to use the questiontecnics we had learnd to ask good questions but it was quite difficult.
different_qual: I would like to have gone deeper with some questions about the places and people the suspect had encounterd. I was afraid of asking too closed or leading question so I keept it very broad during the entire interview which I think was a mistake.

training_qual: I started by letting the suspect tell his own story. Using the evidence report, I targeted him with questions pertaining each floor. It was evident that the suspect was not sticking to the story, therefore I went back and forth with same or similar questions.
different_qual:
Perhaps taken more into account that the suspects answers may not be the same as what I thought they'd be. 

I would have liked to apply all of the - who, what, where and how questions.

training_qual: Opening and closing as instructed. Trying not to alter the persons memory of the event and get their side of the story
different_qual: Maybe I was accusatory when I said that we had CCTV footage of him being in mr. Lukes office

training_qual: I planned to ask open questions and did so fairly well. I introduced myself, the reason for speaking, and thanked the suspect for their time afterwards. I tried not to interrupt the suspect and followed the topics they talked about while trying to ask all the questions that I had written down.
different_qual: I did better this time than the first time, but I believe that is largely due to the suspect's willingness to speak, allowing me to follow the 80/20 protocol better. However, I think I could have asked more specific questions.

training_desc: a course in science in social work
training_qual: I applied the basics - introduction, open questions and then I got from there. It's hard to know what kind of questions to ask when you don't know what they are first going to say. I always tried to think about open questions (even if it's hard sometimes) and clarification. Last I was thinking about having a good ending of the interview.
different_qual: Yes. I could've asked more questions about how both the person in black and the female on the 3rd floor looked like. More detailed questions about the information I didn't already have.

training_qual: I made a plan about how to go about the interviw and what type of questions to ask the suspect. I also made a note of the diffrent places mentions in the casefile so that I could ask the suspect about that. In the interview I tried to ask general to specific questions about the people and places she had been too during the day.
different_qual: I would like to have been more specific in asking what she was doing during the time she spend with her friend in the hospital and gotten more details.

training_qual:
The suspect altered his story several times and couldn't keep the facts straight. Eventually I felt compelled to let the suspect know that I knew he was lying. 

This interview I tried to apply the focus better - who, what, where and how.
different_qual: Perhaps taken a step back once the suspect showed insecurities when he realized that he was caught lying.

training_qual: primarily the introduction and the closing of the interview but also trying to parse out the suspects movement through the building chronologically
different_qual: I think I came of as accusatory and he became a bit defensive as a reaction to this

training_qual: The same way as in the earlier interviews; introduction, open questions, repeating/clarifying story, asking about things that I did and did not have information about.
different_qual: This interview went very well, again, because of the suspect's willingness to speak. There was also a lot to cover as the suspect visited several floors and told me about all of them in fair amount of detail. I tried very hard not to ask suggestive questions (it's very hard not to!), but some still probably slipped through, so that could have gone better. I didn't ask some things that probably would have been good to ask, like why he decided to order an amazon packet to his friends work.

training_qual: Started out with what we learned, however, as we progressed the suspect clearly lied about his events. I tried very hard to stich with the focused questions... at least I think I did
different_qual: This was an interesting case and I would have liked more time especially since he was given contraindicating versions.

training_qual: The suspects activities whilst inside the Walter & Sons building were described in chronological order. Opening and closing of the interview was performed as instructed on day 1 of this study.
different_qual: Perhaps I gave the suspect an easy way out by asking if people in the building had similar clothing (i.e. could be mistaken for her on camera and by witnesses). If I were to redo the interview I would not ask such a narrow and leading question.

training_qual:
I made a summary of what we know and what we dont. I structred a plan outline for me to follow (flexible depending on the answers). 

During the interview I tried to phrase my questions in a non suggestive way as much as i can and tried to gather as much as information from the suspect about what they did and seen so I can have a more detailed time frame besides from what the evidence suggests.
different_qual: Yes, I feel like I could ask them to describe the rooms they were in more details so i would have a better chance in determining if they were in the room that the crime took place. There were moments I felt like summarizing suspect's statements made me question if I was being suggestive.

training_qual: I planned for a good interview opening followed with a broad question like "tell me about your visit", then I'll listen to what the suspect is saying and taking it from there. In my planning i am ready with open questions such as when/what/where/how/who etc. It's hard to plan the exact questions since I'm clueless about what the suspect is going to say after my first question. When the suspect is telling me information then I'm trying to narrowing my questions. And I'm also trying to clarify what the suspect said.
different_qual: Yes, more narrow questions. More clarification.

training_qual: I made a plan beforehand about what I wanted to know more about and how to structure the interview. Then I tried to exicute the interview as planed but I did not get very much information out of the suspect.
different_qual: I would like to have asked more specific questions and been better at getting the suspect to talk and describe his day in more deatils.

training_qual: After our initial training yesterday, I spent a great deal of time thinking/reflecting on what and how I could do things differently. I structured the questions more.
different_qual: Unfortunatly the interview enden only five minutes into the interview as there were technical issues. Based on above answer I was keen on attempting to less suggestive, which I believe that I managed, despite the short time.

training_qual: I started with an introduction and then asked open questions about his day, his visit to the building and what he did beforehand. I asked how questions about information I did not have, such as how he got from one place to another.
different_qual: I don't know if I would have done anything differently. It's still very difficult not to ask leading questions, but I did as best I could. Also, since the suspect denied having been on any of the floors he was seen on, I did not really know what to do. I told him once that we have reason to believe he's been on floor X, so I asked him again where he had been, but he reiterated that he had only been in a cafeteria. Since we had been told to avoid pressuring suspects for answers, I left it there. I was going to thank him for his time after he finished his last answer but the screen froze so I couldn't do that.

training_qual: I gave the person an opportunity to account for what they did at the Zaika Inc. building using there own words and free recall. I opened and closed as instructed. I tried to gather new information primarily about the four most relevant locations and did not press the person on the fact that they had been seen on CCTV camera.
different_qual: I think it was a pretty good interview considering that I have very little experience conducting them

training_qual:
at this point i have sytem to prepare- I sum up what we know, point out important details (floor,colour,numbers etc.). Then I follow a plan flow similar to funnel system. I try to pay attention to which evidence is witness given and which was cctv. 

I believe this interview was my worst so far, because the suspect gave short and brief answers and it was hard to navigate. I feel like I could not get much out from the suspect other than their story's basic line.
different_qual: Yes, I should have ask about all the evidence. The suspect said from the begining that she has been there briefly, she said she only been to 3rd floor and denied that she has been to any other place rather than the elevator and her friends office at the 3rd floor. So I tried to use the camera footage knowledge to point out but she denied. So I felt like there was no room for me to ask about the witness stated evidence to check their accuracy. But now I think I should have ask no matter what.

training_qual: I made a list of the things that I knew and the things that I didn't before the intrview begun to have a clear picture of all the information I had. Then i made a list of questions and topics I wanted to ask the suspect durig the intrview and to have more structure. During the interview I asked more open questions in the beginning, letting him free recall his day and then I came around and asked more focused questions.
different_qual: I would like to have been more discret with the details of the case. It was hard to ask about certian things or topics without giving out to much information about the crime. I would like to have been better at bringing up certain questions discretly.

training_qual: I encouraged the suspect to recall in her own words about the visit and also stipulated that she had a chance to tell her side of the story. During her story she disclosed information that was valuable to use for focus or detailed questioning.
different_qual: I would have liked more time as this suspect provided a lot of good information to work with, i.e present more focus questions.

training_qual: I focused on a good opening and a broad question to start with and then focusing on several open and general questions to more specific questions. I also applied more specific questions just to clarify the answers. When I noticed I lost track I started to steer back with open questions. I had to adjust my plan after he answered my first question. But I always had the when/where/what/who etc in my mind. Then I planned for a good ending with the question if the suspect wanted to add anything.
different_qual: Ask more about the suspects position at his company. More narrow questions about the people he met and talked to. Better structure.

training_qual: I planned using the principles of letting the suspect tell his story at first. Through his story I used the open and focus questions
different_qual: The suspect was very short in his tone, claiming to be in a hurry. I told him that this was his chance to tell his story.Maybe I could have been more direct, listened better?

training_qual: I used the information from the training to make a list of the things that I knew and the things that I didn't and to make a plan for the interview. I wrote down what I wanted to know more about and which locations were important to ask about. Then I applied it in the interview by asking broad questions at first and then narrowing it down to get more specific information from the suspect.
different_qual: I would like to have been a bit more structured during the interview.

training_qual: As like the other interviews I believe I am able to plan out a structure that works for me' following the funnel system. eliminating what we know and we dont. I think also during the interview I find myself altering my questions in a way that it would not be suggestive or very closed. I avoid making commentary about the suspects comments. These are the things I learned from the training. Never the less there are moments where I find myself thinking "well this question will be quite closed and suggestive but i dont see any other way to get the information I need other than this way"
different_qual: I wish I had more tools how to deal with situations where the suspect clearly denies being in a place where the cctv shows they actually went. Once they deny , I take longer to articulate my next question.

training_qual: I made a list of the things I wanted to know more about and the places I wanted to bring up during the interview to make a structure. Then during the interview I opend with explaining the purpose of the interview and then asking about what the suspect did during the day. I also narrowed down on more specific topics of the locations relevent to the crime.
different_qual: I would like to keep the interview going longer so that I could get more information from the suspect. It was difficult to ask broad and non-leading questions while still wanting to know a certain thing.

training_qual: Centered around the relevant locations I asked the suspect about what they had seen and done. I opened and closed the interview as instructed. In the later interviews I have presented part of the evidence that does not match the suspects story which have been fruitful as this generally gets them to admit being in the locations they have been seen on camera or by eye-witnesses.
different_qual: I am unsure, it did not go perfectly but overall I think it was succesful

training_qual: I introduced myself, asked open questions, avoided leading or pressuring the suspect, confirmed what they had said, did not interrupt them, let them speak the majority of the time.
different_qual: The interview went very well, because the suspect was very open and told me almost everything they did immediately. They did not reveal committing the crime, but asking more questions would have been pressuring, so I did not do so. They confirmed most of the information I already had and filled in gaps. I also found out what they were doing prior to the crime.

training_qual: As like the other interviews I started by determining what we know and dont know. For this case I paid extra attention to determine what we know for sure (cctv footage and if the suspect touched the exact bag and shelf that was used for the crime, and that was the case). I tried to follow the funnel system again, there were couple things that did not seem logical so i had to use some closed questions. For example, the suspect described their day and said that they did not realise that a bomb was reported at the company and the building was evacuated and the bomb was defused but he claimed he did not heard or see anything regarding that. He also gave me details about letter gloves and a box cutter and the reason why they had them on him, as well as he mentioned visiting other floors and rooms that was not mentioned in the evidence. So I was suprised but I tried to question those information as the same.
different_qual: I was not prepared for the all the other extra information he gave, I dont think I showed it and tried to question those as well as possible. But I feel like maybe I could have done better with digesting that information, because I had to take some time to decide what to do next since I was outside from my inital structure. But it is hard to navigate these when you dont really know if its just more new info or just more lies.

training_qual: I planned a good opening and open questions, but I had to adapt my questions because I wasn't prepared for so little respond from the suspect. I tried to apply open questions but I felt I asked more closed. And I started to feel stupid for asking how a grocery store looked like when it was a marketing company I had on my papers. I was so focused on my performance that I didn't even notice we had different cases until after the interview..
different_qual: More open questions. I could be more prepared for suspects that don't give much information when asking them open questions.

training_qual: I introduced myself, asked open questions, avoided pressuring or leading the suspect, and tried to attain information that I did not already have as well as conferm information I had.
different_qual: It was difficult to conduct this interview because the suspect was annoyed at being questioned and wanted to know more about the crime. I didn't know exactly how to answer him because the training didn't specify how much we are at liberty to say nor if we should say anything about it at all. It was also somewhat uncomfortable to not know exactly what to say and to be questioned myself, even though I'm the one who is supposed to ask the questions. It all went well of course, but was just more difficult than the other interviews. I also felt like I didn't know exactly how much detail to ask of the suspect; should I ask specifically if he took the master key out of a pocket, touched the trash can, etc.? Well, I established where he was and how he moved from one place to another, as well as what he did beforehand, so I didn't ask such specific, detailed questions. But I still think it was alright. This was fun!

training_qual: I tried to get information without being accusating. When the suspect had inconsistencies with the evidence I tried to get explanations from the suspect. I tried to get information by asking open questions and allowed the suspect to give a recall of their activities. I tried to not ask the same questions twice even when I saw that the suspect was not eager to elaborate.
different_qual: Maybe ask more closed questions but it is hard when the suspect insists with their inconsistencies. I would like to find a way to make the suspect elaborate more.

training_qual: I tried to stay adaptive to the suspect's behavior. I gave information about the evidence to the suspect when I saw that my questions were not enough for the suspect to elaborate. I tried to not force the suspect on their inconsistencies. I insisted on the fact that this is an interview for information and not an accusation.
different_qual: I am sure not if I should have maybe revealed more evidence or on the contrary reveal less

training_qual: I tried to help the suspect remember events without influencing them. I used the evidence to point out the suspect's inconsistencies and allow them to rectify or explain their statement.
different_qual: Maybe insist more on the inconsistencies as suspect seemed cooperative

training_qual: As the suspect gave a lengthy recall of their day I was able to take it piece by piece and get additional information. With the support of evidence I was able to make the suspect give more information, without accusing them.
different_qual: I could have asked more questions about the suspect's activities in between the significant events.

training_qual: I focused on what I did know and tried to confirm when she was onset and point out discrepancies when the information didn't ad up.
different_qual: Better prepared whit what exactly I would say.

training_qual: I noted down the information which was known, a bit more concisely to make it easier to digest, and also ask follow up questions.
different_qual: I would want to conduct the interview with less hesitation and perhaps more direct questions.

training_qual: I prepared for the interview by reading through the case study and picking out important information like evidence and what was reported.
different_qual: The suspect tried to make the interview as difficult as possible, which I wasn't quite prepared for. So I would like to take this experience with me for future interviews, and not rely on my notes too much.

training_qual: I focused on what I knew and tried to se if she had the same story. I wrote everything I knew and structured my questions after my facts.
different_qual: My introduction could be smoother and not to ask why questions.

training_qual: I prepared by analysing the case study and noted down the information already known so to follow the chain of events that had transpired on the day. I let the suspect talk freely about their whereabouts, and posed direct questions when we were getting nowhere. I also prompted the suspect to talk when presenting evidence we already had to see if this could jog their memory.
different_qual: Not sure actually, think I followed my plan pretty well.

training_qual: I based the questions on some things that I knew so she would be more inclined to tell the truth. I also added some small questions that I wanted to know but didn't have an answer for.
different_qual: Not stammer so much and be more precise.

training_qual: I let the suspect speak freely, and tell me about their activities and whereabouts before presenting any evidence. By doing so I did receive more information which was not provided in the brief, for example other people being there which could ptentially be new leads.
different_qual: Not that I can think of. I thinnk this interview went quite well, and had a natural ending when all information was exhausted.

training_qual: I asked questions that I knew the answer to so I can get there story but still point out inconsistencies and get more information.
different_qual: My preparations where a bit rushed so a little more thinking to prepare would have ben good for me.

training_desc: I got interview trainging while preapering for this, it was quite insightfull and really helped with today.
training_qual: I applied as much as I could into preppering for the interview but I didn't really turn out like I hade hoped.
different_qual: I think I should have been more sure about the questions that I was asking and maybe asked more questions, I didn't get as much information that I would have liked.

training_qual: I tried to implement as much as I learned from the training, but it didn't go quite as well as I wanted it to. I had prepared certain questions which I wasn't able to ask and that might have  affected my performance.
different_qual: I think I followed the structure that I wanted but I wasn't able to ask all the questions that I believe were needed to get more information. But I believe that the training helped a lot.

training_qual: As before I think I followed the structure that I wanted but I wasn't able to ask all the questions that I believe were needed to get more information, I feelt like the questions that I could apply were very limited so that's another factor.
different_qual: I think maybe remind the suspect of their role in this, which would have  lead me to  getting more information. It seemed like the suspect wasn't aware about the fact that they were a Staff member, which made it hard to apply certain questions to the interrogation

training_qual: I learned both from my past training and from the interview that I had today, and I decided to inform the suspect of the fact that they were a staff member at the company which allwoed me to gather more information and question the suspect.
different_qual: Something that I would have done diffrently would probably be that I would have asked more leading questions and that might have resulted in me gathering more information from the suspect.

training_desc: Just a littelbit of training in a course called "samtalsmetodik" 15 hp on Gothenburg university.
training_qual: I made a timeline of the four different locations where either CCTV footage documented him or a witness had seen him. And then I tried to ask questions about what he did on all different places.
different_qual: I would have liked to ask follow-up questions immediately after he told new information. I also wanted to ask more about the evidence that CCTV footage had been taken at different places. I also wanted to say "let me think for a second" when I felt stressed and couldn't think of what to ask right away. I also happened to be judgmental and said "interesting" so I'll try not to do that again.

training_qual: I made a timeline of the different places things had disappeared from. Above I wrote some general questions I would ask about the information I did not know about. In the interview, as we learned, I also tried to ask many free recalls and focused questions after that. I also tried to mention that the CCTV camera had seen him on other places which he did not mention.
different_qual: I would like to prepare more questions before and learn some good questions to ask, just to get important information. Maybe I also want to mention that It's really important that they are honest with what they are telling me about. I also would like to talk slower in the beginning and ask more questions about what time the suspect was at the different places.

training_desc: We received a short information about what to think about during an interview before the project.
training_qual: I set my mind on making as open questions as possible and let the suspect lead the interview. During the interview i felt a little confused whether how much information i was suppose to give the suspect due the the suspects passive way and shortness off given information. I did try to ask again about the basement but she rejected being anywhere else than in the reception.
different_qual: Not in this first interview but if I was to have another interview with the same suspect i would like to be more direct and tell her that we have reason to believe she had spent time in the building in more places than just the reception.

training_qual: I started with broad questions and got one story from the suspect but when i narrowed it down and presented some of the evidence the suspects story changed. What i miss from the pre-training we endured is more guidelines in how much evidence we are supposed to tell about to a suspect and how you present it.
different_qual: This interview was hard to get the bigger picture due to digital problems at the other participant(suspect).

training_desc: The short interview training at the GU which is a part of this study
training_qual:
I prepared an outline of what I wanted to say and ask. I made a list of questions (chronological, general to more specific) that could confirm what we already knew about the event and the ones that could answer to what we did not know yet.

I've applied the proper beginning and ending of an interview, I started from general questions like "What have you been doing on that day" and continued to open questions. I gave the suspect time to recall on his own as much as he could before going to focus questions. I tried to order the events chronologically, including what the suspect did before and after his visit in the company. I listened carefully and I did not interrupt the suspect, I let them talk. I adapted my questions to what I heard from the suspect and I believe I did not ask any suggestive questions.
different_qual: I could find a room for more open and focused questions. I also felt like the shift from one topic to another was not the best, it maybe could be smoother. I should also keep more eye contact but because of the short preparation time I did nit have time to learn my questions and I'm not the sponatneous type.

training_desc: training as part of the study
training_qual:
'-formulated introduction to open the interview and lead to boyle group as topic
-drew a funnel with 
Q1: open question: recalling the day 
Q2s: identify info to gather regarding timeline , suspects actions and available evidence.
- reason for visit? duration of visit? time of arrival
-  ...
different_qual:
well, how about everything... except the planning.

I got totally thrown off by the very short, few words recall / response to the open question. 
I am myself personally very much oversharing, overexplaining... and I am used to people talking plenty to me. But I did not see coming how I would stumble over being given very short answer. I was not able to adapt and find a segway to my planned questions. I got stuck in trying to get the suspect to talk more freely. Somewhat waisted time (?) and on top of that I lost track of time.
However I believe learned at least that there were plenty of discrepancies, since the answers I got were not consistent with the evidence. But I never got around to address that properly. I was dancing around too much with open questions. Well, it got me information to further pursue, even information to assume inconsistencies. But I missed to adress this within the time limit. Again, I believe I stood in my own way, being a bit over-aware in this situation regarding being unaccusatory and open, usually I am pretty unapologetically direct.
 PS: the start were the suspect asked me admin-questions, eg if he could lie to me to convince me of his innocence was quite entertaining :)

training_qual:
I prepared an outline of what I wanted to cover, the things I already know and the things I don't know yet. I prepared a list of questions  (chronologically, from general to specific) to confirm the information I have and to fill in the gaps. 


During the interview I let the suspect talk, I did not interrupt but I kept track of the information the suspect gave me and later I tried to adjust my questioning plan accordingly. I I started from free recall questions and then followed with opened and focused questions. I tried to keep questions in a chronological order according to the events  but I might have get lost and confused at some point. I tried to avoid suggestive questions but I think once I might have asked such a question. I opened and closed the interview in a way we were taught during the short training.
different_qual: I'm not sure but I might have gotten lost in the chronological order of asking questions so I could improve that. I shouls also make sure not to ask any suggestive questions.

training_qual: I tried using open questions but i think the suspect felt very personal attacked which also is understandable because the situation is under serious pressure. I felt that i got compliance but not collaborating the way i would have wanted.
different_qual: It's hard to take notes and not make the person feel pressured so I would like to train taking smaller and more effiiciant notes to make the suspect not feel like i'm judging and writing down everything they say.

training_qual: This time I used a more open and not accusing way of presenting why we are there and why the suspect was being interviewed. I felt that it made the suspect more open and willing to express his story even though it does not always match up by the evidence.
different_qual: No

training_qual:
While planning the interview, I focused on keeping the questions open, but relevant to the crime. I planned the introduction in a direct but non-accusatory way. I planned relevant follow-up questions to gather more informations about topics, without making the questions suggestive or closed. 

While conducting the interview, I opened the interview like I had planned, but when the interview did not take the route I had planned, I had to adapt. When the suspects statements did not have any clear connection to the information regarding the case, as well as them claiming they did not know about the company, I started asking more general questions to gather information about their daily activities and affliations. I closed the interview as we were taught in the training; informing about the interview coming to a close, asking if they would like to add anything, and thanking them for their time.
different_qual:
I should have prepared myself for the possibility that they would not share any information that would be directly connected to the case. My planned outline was focused on the case, but did not take into consideration that they could go in a completely different direction. 

While performing the interview, I might have asked a few suggestive or closed questions where I could have asked open ones instead, which would have been prefered.

training_qual:
Planning: Last interview did not give me much information connected to the case, so I considered mentioning to the suspect that they are a suspect because we had witnesses that had seen them at locations connected to the crimes scene. But, because the training emphasised on not applying pressure (which the mentioning of witnesses definetely would), I decided not to mention it. I kept the questions quite open. 

Performance: I followed my planned structure quite well, but I decided not to ask further questions about the suspects activity at Walter and Sons because I got a bit confused about its connection to the library mentioned by the suspect. As it was my first interview with the suspect in this investigation, I did not want to risk their cooperation this early by showing my inattention or contradicting them.
different_qual: I would like to have kept the interview more naturally structured, as I jumped between subjects quite unnaturally at times. I am also unsure about the ending, where the suspect stated that they did not know why they were a suspect, whether I should have informed them about it (which I think would be appropriate in a real interview) or just ended the interview like I did. Because of my limited knowledge and information, I did not want to risk their cooperation by telling them about the witnesses and footage, but I think that telling them something less pressuring would have been more appropriate than just leaving them.

training_qual: I tried to make a lot of open prompts, and sometimes afterwards some focused questions and closed questions.
different_qual: I didn really have time time to prepare all question so I would like speed up my planning process to have time to write down all my questions. Next time I will try to remember to both inform about the consistency and the inconsistencies!

training_qual:
Just as with the other interviews, I made a line where I placed the various pieces of evidence in the order in which they were assumed to have occurred. Then I wrote questions for each of these pieces of evidence. So there were 4 different subjects for which I wrote questions for. For each subject, I applied the technique open - prompts - focused - closed. 
This interview was the only one I had time to prepare all the questions, as I had enough time to prepare. 
During the interview, I hardly looked at the questions, but writing them down helped me figure out what I needed to ask later.
different_qual:
Instead of saying: you were in this room... I would like to say: If I understood you right You were in this room...

I forgot to reinforce when she actually told me things that matched the evidence that was available. It could have helped her to want to tell more. I also would have liked to ask more focused questions like "Was there anyone else in the basement?"
I think I accidentally asked some leading questions, so I would have liked to take my time when formulating questions at the moment. So if I'm feeling stressed, I think it's better to say "Let me think for a second". Instead of accidentally asking a leading question.

training_desc: In a legal psych class, but what i felt i learned was that its super hard. I used cognitive interview once and maybe another one but i dont really remember.
training_qual:
I used the opening and closing lines provided from the training as well as what to say when i had conflicting evidence. I focused on not saying suggestive things and not being accusatory.
When planning i focused on narrowing down on each touchpoint provided by the timeline i did as well as trying to find out if there were additional things left out.
different_qual: I would like to ask more questions getting the suspect to elaborate on each of my main areas of questions. I feel i need to disregard my uncomfortableness of someone not being very forthcomming. I felt i was more uncomfortable then the suspect when they had to explain away discrepancies. maybe i also need to take more time, i felt i may have ended my questioning too early because it was hard and i did not know really how to continue.

training_qual:
i feel i planned very well for the interview, better then my first interview. i focused on what i did not know and what i would like to knnow as well as what informartion i had which would be good to know. I also felt i focused the planning more on other things discussed in the first training session with more open questions first and then open ended questions so i would remember to use them this time. 
But then during the actual interview i felt it was very hard to apply it. I felt the suspect maybe not really had undestood the task or hadnt gotten the information i had. In my description it was said they had been picked up outside of the boyle group building and when i asked aout their visit at the building they sayd hey hadnt been there. I had also been told in the training that we were supposed to trust the evidence presented as correct but the suspect only repeatedly said that he could have been confused for someone else. i till tried to apply some of my planning but it was hard. I do think this suspect would have been hard to interview no matter what. 
I felt i did not get the opportunity to really do an investigative interview. Mostly because of how he answered but i felt we had some trouble communicating as well.
different_qual:
I dont think i personally could really have done anything differently other than maybe ending it earlier for my own sake. this is because i felt increasingly uncomfortable. i felt my suspect was condescending towards me and laughing at me in a way. 
i also felt i got almost angry at him for the way he handled the interview but in my head i couldnt do anything as i was not supposed to put any pressure on him but i didnt know the middle ground between saying that he really did not make any sense and not being rude about it. maybe i could have found a better way to tell him he wasnt making sense at all.
I am sad because i feel like i did my best and then it was hard to be but in a situation where i felt i had no control at al, it made me feel powerless which was not pleasant.

training_qual: I identified the information that I know and these ones that I do not know and I prepared questions accordingly, to check if what I already know fits to what the suspect will say and to fill in the gaps in my knowledge about the events of that day. I prepared questions in a chronological order, starting from free recall questions, through open questions to focused questions. I tried to avoid closed questions. I let the suspect talk as much as they wanted, I tried not to be judgemental or accusive. I also tried to get to know if there are any relations between the suspect and the victim, anything that could push thr suspect to criminal behaviour against the victim. When the suspect said something contrary to what the evidence showed, I tried to gently say that we have an evidence telling othervise and I asked for clarification. When the suspects ansvers were too vague I let go and moved on.
different_qual: Next time I would like to be able to cross-question the suspect better. When he/she gives me vague answers I back off but I would like to know how to skilfully keep this interrogation going to get more information about a particular question instead of moving on to the next one, but without making it awkward or causing any tensions.

training_qual: I identified the information that I know and these ones that I do not know and I prepared questions accordingly, to check if what I already know fits to what the suspect will say and to fill in the gaps in my knowledge about the events of that day. I prepared questions in a chronological order, starting from free recall questions, through open questions to focused questions. I tried to avoid closed questions. I let the suspect talk as much as they wanted, I tried not to be judgemental or accusive. I also tried to get to know if the suspect has any IT skills that could have make it easier for her to commit the cybercrime. When the suspect said something contrary to what the evidence showed, I tried to gently say that we have an evidence telling othervise and I asked for clarification. When the suspects ansvers were too vague I let go and moved on.
different_qual: I did not know how to behave when the suspect said "show me the evidence and then I'll tell you if it was me" etc so I just moved on to the next question and that could be a bit awkward or weird. For the next time I would like to know how to handle better such situations.

training_desc: a brief training at department of psychology in gothenburg
training_qual: funneling, not being to accusive, giving suspect a chance to clarify
different_qual: most of it, i was nervous and my mind was everywhere so did not manage to follow my plan.

training_qual: letting suspect speak freely. asking general questions. using supportive transition and moving on when they answer no.
different_qual: maybe follow timeline better and not asking about gang affiliation

training_qual: I thought about keeping my questions open and in a funnel form, as well as following a chronological order of the events. I planned to ask questions like "tell me more" and wrote down things to say for my opening and ending. I also planned out the order in which i would reveal the information i knew. I feel I was able to follow my planning well during the interview. When additional information was told by the suspect, which i did not previously know, i tried to use the same type of questions as before.
different_qual: I really liked how this interview went. I would maybe try mentioning the things that were actually stolen or tampered with but I do not know how without being leading in my questioning. I sometimes had to rephrase my questions as it is hard not to fall into an accusatory tone when you suspect you are being lied to so I guess i maybe would like to be even more open to the suspects story but it is hard when it goes against the evidence.

training_desc: I attended a 2hour lecture at the school of psychology, university of gothenburg, where i was taught on the basis of an investigative interview and what the processes, guide and expectations are when you interview a suspect
training_qual: As a way to prepare for the interview, i made an outline arranging all the details i intended to expand on in a chronological order following the order of the reported case in the case file. i was careful to avoid suggestive questions and even when i knew the answers to some of the events, i still featured them in my questions and i think it helped with the interview.
different_qual: I did not ask some of the followup questions in the order that i should have asked them. Ideally, that would have led to even more new information if i was able to followup most questions immediately

training_qual: I planned the interview with relevant questions that were open from the most important things i wished to find out and guessed a few follow up questions too. Unfortunately, i did not imagine speaking to with a totally uncooperative suspect and so, i was practically unable to get any useful information
different_qual: I am interested in learning other ways of interviewing suspects who cleary plan to be uncooperative and gain useful information without throwing accusations or being suggestive. If i know better, maybe i will handle a similair interview more productively

training_qual: I wrote down open questions and tried to use funnel structure. I planned outthe order in which to talk about things that i had information about. I made a timeline of the events so it was easier to see what i did not know. Through this it became evident that the suspect, if guilty, probably would had to have gone some place else after the library as they would have moved the murder weapon before being brought in for questioning. When doing the interview i felt i could follow my plan and still be very flexible based on what information i was told. I feel i "winged it" off of my plan and it worked okay.
different_qual: I cant really think of anything i would have liked to do differently in this situation, most things are related to being able to ask more questions that a "real suspect" would know, like about the other people around and more details about the surroundings. I did notice i had to catch myself from phrasing my questions accusatorily but that was mostly when the suspect had said something themselves that did sound odd.

training_qual:
During the planning, I prepared some questions related to the evidence, with which I could compare to the answers I got, and then confirm or question it based upon the evidence. I also made a back-up plan of questions if they were to deny everything that matched the evidence. 

During the interview, I got a little suprised when they started expressing how they felt very attacked by this interview and the accusations, because this lead the interview completely off track. I had to improvise a bit based upon what objectives we had learned about during the training, so what I did was trying to let them calm down a bit to loosen the tension that had built up. I did it by listening and not trying to get them to answer further questions about their whereabouts and doings.
different_qual: I should have prepared myself that this is a possible reaction in an interview, so that I would not have been taken aback as much as I did.

training_qual:
During the planning, I applied the training by planning both open questions, as well as some more specific targeting the areas related to the crime. I also planned a few questions that could give general information that could render itself useful during the investigation, e.g what they work with, and if they know anyone at the company where the crime happened.

During the interview, I applied the training by trying the SOS technique, but when they did not provide any more information after two attempts, I gave up so that I could maintain their cooperation for other questions.
different_qual: I feel like I could have planned better for the option that they would not give information related to the crime, such as a few more questions that could at least give us something to work with.

training_qual:
I tried to make a detailed timeline from the known facts. I also tried to understand what could be the crucial missing parts and what information would be needed to fill them up. 

I tried to ask questions open-ended questions to fill out the missing parts. It was a bit unexpected that the suspect did not give statements that were according to the recorded timeline (ground truth). Then, I had to inform the suspect that there is evidence of them doing a certain act at a certain place. However, it was interesting to see that the suspect changed their statements after I mentioned the evidence. I am not really sure if this was according to the training I received  previously.
different_qual: I felt a bit socially awkward facing a suspect that was not telling the truth. It made me feel a bit nervous. I should have been more mentally prepared to know that the "suspect" was going to be difficult and not tell the "truth" in the interview.

training_qual:
I tried to make a detailed timeline from the known facts. I also tried to understand what could be the crucial missing parts and what information would be needed to fill them up. 

I tried to ask questions open-ended questions to fill out the missing parts. This time, I was expecting the interviewee to be "difficult". Therefore, I tried to work with what he gave me, and I tried to form questions to understand what he was willing to explain. For example, when he gave me some irrelevant information regarding a smiling nurse passing by quickly on the 4th floor, I tried to ask questions regarding this nurse. I felt this made him more open and he put his "guards" down.
different_qual: In retrospect, I would have have formed my questions slightly differently.

training_desc: Counducting interview training with emphasis on memory processing and social psycholocy phenomenon such as heuristics, reactance, non-suggestive questioning and focus on keeping cooparation / avoiding compliance. Also focus on reflexive listening. 1.5 hour of training in total.
training_qual: I focused on laying out first the incidents, then the evidence and sketch out all the information given to me by the case-studie (names, floornumbers etc.). When so, time had passed and I got little to no time with preparing questions towards the suspects. Earlier training focused on open questions, with minimal suggestive new information. In reality it was tricky to balance my focus between applying interview-technique and at the same time learn the case.
different_qual: Keeping more cool, less nervous and avoid staking. Also try to formulate more short and concise question. Less talkning overall. I would like to have more time planning the questions, preparatory to the interview. 10 minutes is not enough time.

training_qual:
I learned from the first interview to be more short and concise in questions, while still focus on beeing reflexive in listening so I could gathering more information without adding anything new. So I spent my preparing time of 15 minutes thinking about and formulate various open questions. Also, I prepared a start/opening sequence, a closing sequence and managed to somewhat apply those parts.

Now that I knew more about the roleplay-act, I could let go of some stress relating to confusion.
different_qual:
I really felt the urge to let this one person "go", since there was not much more he could add to his story. In the moment I thought there was nothing more to ask about his stay, after explaining the 20 minutes spent in a meeting room on 2nd floor, and visiting some room for coffe higher up the building. 

I could have asked more about the meeting-room in specific; layout, funiture and devices. Perhaps he would have given more details about this if given the oppurtunity to do so.

training_qual: I developed questions based on the evidence i already had about the case and tried to ask some open questions to enable a free recall and the a few focused questions. I also had considered possible inconsistent response from the suspect so i added a reminder of the existing evidence and the need to have them make a second attempt at the same questions
different_qual: i cannot think of anything i could have done differently regarding the interview

training_qual: I prepared an outline with open question to allow for a free recall and general comments from the suspect that could lead the interview to a narror end. I developed some focused questions and follow ups  and i started the interview exactly as planned with hopes of improvising if there was a need.
different_qual: I actually believe i followed the process of the interview as i should and there is probably nothing i could have done differently.

training_qual:
Focused on having a separate line of questioning for each evidence item (cctv, witness)
Free recall and then more direct questions, regarding each item
Collect talking points from free recall and merge them later with the direct questions (possible  tension relieve)
different_qual:
General reflection: I was more aware of the timer this time. Though my last question was unfortunately cut off still. 
I realized that this suspect was more talkative and spoke freely - this made it easier for me- also to formulate/ select my next question. 
I was able to address all 4 evidence items and even find inconsistencies, I gave several opportunities to change the story. Though suspect stuck to his version. Slight nervousness arouse, but no tension really i think. That felt like a success. Since we could keep talking. Though the question is really if anything usefull was said after the inconcitencies were identified.
Would like to change: I noticed clearly that I have no idea what to do, when the evidence (cctv) is questioned... I have in this setting no opportunity to show it. And it did not feel productive to just insist on that I have seen it and that it is clearly the suspect. So it turns into a dead end.

training_qual:
Same as before. But I think my preparations lacks some details, because i easily get stuck before asking a follow up question. Lack of routine maybe? 
Plan: Free recall, note down all evidence items and go through each one separately after free recall when asking a mix between open and more detailed questions.
Adress possible new info given in free recall.
different_qual:
She was so talkative that i had no other choice then to interrupt her. She liked going of on tangents too,  which could be a strategy or just personality trade.
No hard feelings about being interrupted though I guess. Open communication all the time.
But even though the evidence seemed more convincing on paper this time, there was no clear inconsistencies, there was more i don't remember then denial in her answers.
I learned she was a new empolyee of about 1 week, and needed money, therefore the job. Which can be indicative for both innocence or involvement. :)
She did not seem to know what the incindence was or what I was looking for information about. So i am questioning now how much information I need to give about "the incident" , maybe to steer the conversation more.

training_qual: Same prepp as before. Clearing up evidence items for me and timeline. start with open recall and try to adress each item separatelty later.
different_qual:
She was a very realistic counterpart I think. And also she was very evasive in her answers and did not commit to anything more that being in the building; getting lost and being basically everywhere and nowhere is hard to argue against. Also CCTV looses relevance. Presented with CCTV only the fridge interaction could be confirmed. 
I did not find a good way to figure out any relation to either Lepus och Timothy L. maybe there is none, or maybe i did not find the right question to ask.
I have a few conclusions:
- its difficult!! interviewing a total stranger about a handful of information about an unknown place is very difficult.
- collecting information, when you dont really know what exactly, is also difficult.
- Also I am way to polite I think? I lost my edge - above situation makes me apparently very un-confrontative and careful. First I thought i was overthinking the raining tips, now i thinks its just being "unprepared"/not used to/ outside comfort zone with the situation.
- the lack of details and depth of information makes asking follow up questions diffcult, at least as i experienced it, since there is nothing more to say than "there is cctv". It feels shallow.
- Having no preconceived assumption makes leading the interview difficult. Having an assumption (on paper) and having that met by a stranger is confusing. :) 
- I wish at least the relation of the suspect to the Inc. in question would have been known. Or other background information to have kind of a place to put them in ... you know, I guess I want to have a start assumption to get confused by later:) 
- more info on timeline, cctv timestamps maybe and day of the week, could have made a little difference and an opportunity to ask more detailed maybe. (less shallow)

training_desc: The training received on Saturday for this study.
training_qual: I applied the training by planing out the start and the end and by trying to start with open questions and get more specific on the details.
different_qual: I would have liked to conceal more that I am aware that the suspect might be lying since cctv evidence was denied.

training_qual:
I used it again for the beginning and the end and the general questions like "Tell me about your day", etc.
However, I think I got lost in the interview and did not apply my training throughout the whole interview. Especially, regarding follow-up questions and the do not's
different_qual:
I think I ended up giving more information than I should have.
At one time I had the feeling that I asked something close to a suggestive question. So, I would most definitely try to avoid that.

training_qual: Funnel down, start general
different_qual: Push harder, torture if needed

training_qual: Starting general and letting the suspect do most of the talking
different_qual: Most of it, i get nervous and cant folow my plan

training_qual:
I did what I had learned with identifying objectives bases on case material. I did try to understand the suspects movements in timely order aswell as his motiv for visiting the company. This was really hard do to 1) bad internet connections, before and after the headphones were taken off suspect. 2)language barrier, accent hard for me as schooled with brittish english and/ or american accent. 3)I got confused and got stressed over 
A: not beeing able to respectfullt listen via my own difficulty in understanding suspect and 
B: getting hight levels of self-awerness and
C: stressing over potentiall biases in our non-balanced power-situation and thoose biases  getting worse due to bad start, my struggle in understanding the suspect in accent.
different_qual:
I did my best with limited training as a mock-interviewer and my best as a reflexive listening part. 

Yet, I would like to have not affected in stress and confusion due to his strange motiv and movements visiting the buiding- as this made the interview much harder (relating to my earlier 1 &2). I strongly belive my limitations in training and lack of experience in interrigations was misleading the interview in multiple ways.

training_qual:
My focus was to map out the suspects movements, activities and new information about her visiting upon Walter ans Sons. I got the name wrong in the beginning and that was a sad miss.

I planned the interview the same way as the three earlier ones. Upon this last one I felt more confident in structure. Still I find it to be a stressful situation asking these questions with a minimal amount of actual training. 

I found it less stressful in this interview compairing to the one before (3rd one). This is likely to do with me and having an investigation role, and being more familiar with the "play" / "mock-situation". But it is also likely to differ in relation to the suspects and the interpersonal-dynamics biased by gender, language and possibly strereotyping-aspects.
different_qual:
I forgot to ask the suspect further questions concerning her relation to the man she was lookning for. Also I did not want to be leadning or suggestive in asking about this male friend, since I in advance knew the interview was concering a murder and it not professional to be assuming facts in advance.This was a tricky case, and I felt an urge to be very limited in asking only open and focused questions (funnel-structure thinking). It is likely
due to errors in my 3rd interview, were I felt stressed over the suspects "strange" story. Having this experience going in to the 4rd interview certainly influensed my preformance.

training_qual:
I tried to make a detailed timeline from the known facts. I also tried to understand what could be the crucial missing parts and what information would be needed to fill them up. I started with open-ended questions, and I tried to stick with the plan I made before the interview.

The suspect provided very little new information, and at some point it felt like he was repeating himself. At that point, I thanked him and concluded the interview.
different_qual: I feel at some point the atmosphere got a bit tense. If I do it again, I would try to keep a more neutral tone.

training_qual:
I tried to make a detailed timeline from the known facts. I also tried to understand what could be the crucial missing parts and what information would be needed to fill them up. 

I tried stick to with open-ended questions and having a neutral tone. The suspect gave some new information, but the quality of the information may not be super relevant to the investigations.
different_qual: The suspect had a totally different type of character than the previous suspects. In the hindsight, I could have potentially used this fact to adjust the plan to have a better flow in the investigation.

training_qual: This time I planned out a few questions to every piece of evidence that was provided. Therefore, I had a better idea on how to structure the interview: general open questions, followed by questions concerning each piece of evidence.
different_qual: I would have liked to defuse the situation more easily. I think I acted a bit uninterested.

training_qual: I prepared questions regarding the different evidence pieces and implemented them in the general questions I prepared for the interview.
different_qual: I was a bit surprised because this participant was very forthcoming with questions, so I missed getting into more detail at a few points. I would like to get a few more details surrounding certain evidence that was not already given at the beginning.

training_qual: I tried to plan a basic structure and then conform and clarify the suspects answers and then tried to come up with questions based on what the subject was saying.
different_qual: It felt I ended it too abruptly. but I didn't have any further questions so perhaps I could've prepared some more, but it is also difficult to prepare more focused questions without knowing what the subject will say.

training_qual: Tried to ask questions without judgement, and when I wasn't getting anywhere I had to asked a focused question but she said no which meant I had to stop since I couldn't accuse. but I wasn't sure of how to continue. Although I don't know either how I could have prepared more since the subject just plainly stated they had not left their desk.
different_qual: I'm not sure

training_desc: I have studied interview techniques in the course forensic psychology at Göteborgs universitet
training_qual: I traced a timeline of the events and planned out some open questions beforehand. I also planned how I were supposed to disclose the evidence if there was any inconsistencies.
different_qual: I was not pleased with my adaptation to the suspects story and should have asked more questions about what they were saying before disclosing evidence but it was hard because the suspect didn't give me much information to work with.

training_qual: I planned out the evidence that I had and made a timeline. I also wrote down a few questions I could ask trying to be open and getting more information at the same time.
different_qual: It is hard to ask follow up questions after confronting the person with evidence that keeps being inconsistent without accusing the person to have committed the crime so that is something I could try to work on and try a different tactic but I'm not really sure how.

training_qual: I wrote down all the information from the case that was relevant and wrote some specific topics to talk about. I also wrote down exactly how to ask some questions and outlined the structure of the interview.
different_qual: I think I could have asked some more follow-up questions that wasn't directly linked to the case instead of moving on too quickly.

training_qual: I outlined what information was of importance and then wrote some questions regarding topics I would like to have answered and what I could ask if the answer wasn't consistent with the evidence. I also tried changing to order before talking about the suspect's day at the company to get more information from the suspect.
different_qual: I would have asked more questions about the suspect's certainty in their answers to make it more difficult to change their story when introduced to the evidence.

training_qual: I tried to ask open questions as much as possible.
different_qual: Id like to repeat myself less

training_qual: In the planning stage I tried to make a structure after what we had learned from the training so I started with an opening where I stated the reason for the meeting and that the person was a suspect and then go over to a free recall question. This I also followed in the interview. I also planned what I wanted to get to know from the suspect regarding what, when, where and why. Lastly I ended with a question about what they would like to add, as we had learned. I also tried not to ask leading questions.
different_qual: I would like to have made it clearer in the beginning that I asked about a walk through of that day in particular and not just any day.

training_qual: Tried to stick to open questions but it resulted in very little. I repeated questions quite a lot and Im not sure if that is good or not.
different_qual: No. Given the information I had its went well but Im sure face to face interview would be better.

training_qual: On interview 2: I tried to use the same structure for the planning and performance as in the first interview but now specified that it was that day that I want to know about in the free recall question. When getting to know if the suspect knows the target I used a closed question followed up by a focused question as recommended in the training when the suspect initially did not bring it up.
different_qual: Upon reflecting I should have asked more follow up questions about when the suspect was in the staff kitchen since that was a place of interest.

training_qual: I began reading the document and wrote down the information i was provided. Afterwards i wrote down some questions and practiced to myself of how different scenarios could have gone.
different_qual: I assume that if i had some back-up questions to give me a bit of a nudge i would have probably gotten a bit further. Although i tried to interview the suspect with as many questions to get more information.

training_qual: As i informed before, i wrote down the evidence and information that was known and wrote a few questions to help me get the conversation going. The suspect was being talkative which made it easier to just ask follow ups questions. Nothing in partially of "training" was done just tried to let the suspect speak and ask follow up questions to the gaps he left.
different_qual: I was getting to the point of asking the questions that could get me some information but the time run out. Could mayhaps get more to the point with my questions.

training_qual: Tried to stay with open questions but had to be more specific to find more info
different_qual: Focus more on the timeline of events

training_qual: started with open questions but since suspect didnt remember much I had to be more confrontational. with very little success.
different_qual: Im not sure. Very hard when the answer is: I dont remember.

training_qual: I structured the questions like I did in training.
different_qual: well it did feel like she got a bit defensive and it was hard to tell her about the evidence without her just straight up denying it. But on the other hand I don't know how I could have made it differently.

training_qual: Since not knowing the suspects profession before hand It was difficult to plan questions, so I had to improvise a bit more on this one, but it felt better than the others
different_qual: known the suspects profession

training_qual: As i have done on the two previous interviews, i read the summary and the evidence i had and thought of questions to perform this interview. I did plan a structure but the suspect was not denying nor beinf resistant in the questions i have given so there wasnt any neccesary back up questions.
different_qual: I could have gone a bit more forward and give out more evidence but in my opinion it would have just form other stories and the suspect would feel the urge to defend themselves more.

training_qual: i tried to keep the questions as open as possible in order to make the suspect talk more open. sometimes came back to the same questions and repeated myself in case he would change information. i was not very offensive or attacking when asking my question, i also tried to keep what i knew about the  case to a minimum.
different_qual: not what i directly can think of.

training_qual: Basically as before, read the evidence and summary, create a structure of questions and ask questions that suit the interview.
different_qual: Not something that i could think of that could have helped me.

training_qual: i tried to keep the question open and be more and more narrow during the interview. i tried not to rush the questions.
different_qual: not that i can think of directly

training_qual: i try to listen and find room for further questions from the suspects testimony. i try to start with more open questions and narrow it down more closely. i also try not to accuse the person in the questions i ask him.
different_qual: not that i can think of right now.

training_qual: i started with open questions in order to narrow it down but since i got 100% denial from the suspect about being in the building it was hard to keep the conversation going.
different_qual: maybe try more angles in the questions for him to open up but i doubt i would have succed in this case.

training_qual: I tried to make a structure with what questions I wanted to get answered where I started with an open question and then went into a mix between focused and closed questions to get to where I wanted. This I did with every piece of evidence to make sure that the evidence and the statement lines up.
different_qual: I would like to have put more focus on details that I got to know that I felt may have been significant but accidentally passed over.

training_qual: Like last time, I made a structured plan about what I wanted to cover in the interview in almost like a grid with the different questions and in what order. It felt easier to follow through with the plan this time but still let the interview run its cause. I also during the interview used the shift-of-strategy approach where I told the suspect if the statement lined up with the evidence.
different_qual: I feel like I sometimes rushed my next question when I thought the suspect had finished but it was only a little paus so I may have missed som information.

training_desc: A 2 hour lecture on interrogation, how to plan an interrogation, memory and how to formulate questions.
training_qual: I wrote some questions that i wanted to ask the suspect, such as What she did on the day of the theft, what floors she was on and what she did on those floors, where she worked, how she got access to the building and more specific questions about the items that were stolen.
different_qual: Im not sure, I felt I asked what I wanted to ask, I didn't get all the answer about her whereabouts on that day or what she did fully but I don't think it was because my line of questioning.  Only thing i remember i forgot was to give her a chance to speak or add anything after I had no questions left.

training_qual: I had prepared some questions in a chronological order. I made a list of things that I knew and didn't. I tried to ask the questions in order and I asked her all of the questions that I had prepared.
different_qual: I don't think so, I felt I asked all the questions i had prepared and got a decent amount of information about her whereabouts and doings on the day of the incident. Only thing i can think of now is maybe asking questions about what she did next or what she did before to get a more clear whole picture about what she did on the day.

training_qual: I used the training of being neutral, open minded, cooperative to conduct this interview. I tried to stay away from suggestive or commentary statements, used funnel structure strategy of open-ended questions to specific ones. I opened and closed the interview in a formal, direct yet cooperative way.
different_qual:
I believed that some of the questions were slightly suggestive in nature. This was done to get an answer out of the suspect regarding a question but this may have to lead to false memory re-creation.

Another aspect which I felt was a misstep was that I asked the suspect about their relation with the murderer, when they didn't know who the murderer was.

Lastly, I could have asked more concrete questions in a more direct way to get more substantial answers.

training_qual: I applied the principles of my training to the fullest to ensure a cooperative, non-intrusive, and neutral interview. I observed the interview as a neutral, direct and cooperative interrogator who used a funnel shaped structure for questions starting from open ended questions and trickling down to more specific ones in the end, and then to open ended ones again.
different_qual:
I applied the principles of my training to the fullest to ensure a cooperative, non-intrusive, and neutral interview. The statement of the "suspect" meant that there was direct denial of established evidence, so that led to a pretty short interview where not much additional information was being extracted. 

But since this was done according to the interrogation training principles, so I would not have done anything else much differently.

training_qual:
It was difficult not to get straight answers when you didn't want to be too direct so that suspicion would arise. 
Don't talk too much and eventually they will do the talking for you
different_qual: Don't be so nervous it shows because the other person will sense it and take advantage of it in worst case scenario

training_qual: Let them do the talking for you. Try to go back to previous mentions things later to try to get more information.
different_qual: Not what i could think of

training_qual: Use a polite approach to avoid suspicion and ask to help you understand if something doesn't add up with the evidence and testimony
different_qual: When the suspekt withheld information, you always need to use the evidence for help and it feels like you could have done this in a different way to avoid presenting to much of the information I have

training_qual: I think i messed up this time and didnt use the trainig as much as would like to
different_qual: It was a lot harder to get information this time so i would like to have more time to sketch more on my plan.

training_qual: I planned an introduction and some free recall questions to follow, then moving to more specific but still open-ended questions and slowly moving to more and more specific questions, when it came to inconsistencies i pointed them out to the suspect.
different_qual: At the moment i can't think of much, I felt it went pretty well and that I got a better picture of what the suspect did on the day.

training_qual: I started by identifying what evidence i had for the case and what i wanted to find out, i noted all the different points of interest such as what items were stolen and where they were located. I then prepared some questions that were in line with what i wanted to find out, they were put in so they would also give the suspect a lot of room to talk and explain and the questions got more and more specific the more i asked.
different_qual: I think i misunderstood the suspect a couple times and that could've been prevented by me making sure i understood by asking him to repeat his answer. And i feel i sometimes said too much in a question that would simply make the answer a yes or no question instead of giving the suspect more of a chance to explain it himself.

training_qual: I used the Shift of Strategy approach in addition to the regular approach to try and analyze the suspect in a neutral and diplomatic manner. I framed my questions in a way that it was non-subjective and diplomatic yet direct. The questions were framed via a funnel strategy where we went from broad questions to then specific ones, and in a chronological order.
different_qual: Nothing much different. Apart from the fact that the "suspect" turned hostile even when asked questions diplomatically, and refused to believe in the existence of evidence and requested to be shown the same, so maybe better de-escalation strategies would have helped the scenario.

training_qual: Used Shift of strategy approach to approach the interview with a neutral, non subjective yet direct approach to all my questions. I tried to ask specific questions and shifted my strategy a bit to get to know some additional information that I didn't knew.
different_qual: I could have used a strategy to try and get more information from the "suspect" that I didn't knew about, since I felt that there were many open ends to the answers which could have been followed upon, with the downside being that this new information may or may not have been valid to the current case study investigation.
